abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome was rated
            satisfactory. The project was mostly devoted to supporting
            capitalization and its related legal reforms, which were
            highly satisfactory. The government's commitment, both
            in the political, and technical fields, allowed for a rapid,
            though demanding, reform program. The key lessons learned
            suggest privatization should better be preceded by the
            establishment of a legal and regulatory framework, designed
            to promote competition, and efficiency. Obviously,
            Governments tend to focus - primarily - on transactions,
            upon the divestiture of large state-owned enterprises, to
            the detriment of the accompanying legal and regulatory
            reforms. However, the Bank can emphasize these latter
            aspects through advice, and, guidance on best practices, as
            well as through the initial financing of regulatory
            agencies. The provision of technical assistance (TA) in a
            stand-alone operation, i.e., separate from an adjustment
            operation, allows maximum flexibility. As in this case, TA
            allowed for better support to preparatory efforts, as well
            as for the demonstrated commitment to satisfy an up-front
            conditionality on adjustment operations. TA projects are not
            designed to handle procurement procedures involving prior
            review; however, combining prior review thresholds with
            ex-post review mechanisms, could prove effective.
